strategic_profile.executive_summary: A Catholic research university known for its robust engineering programs, commitment to community engagement, and strong alumni network.
strategic_profile.market_position: Strong regional player with growing national recognition for experiential learning.
strategic_profile.admissions_philosophy: Holistic review with a focus on academic achievement, leadership potential, and commitment to service-learning.

analyst_takeaways.takeaway: Strong value proposition for engineering students seeking hands-on experience.
Potential for increased national visibility through targeted marketing of unique programs.
Opportunities to leverage alumni network for career placement and philanthropy.

campus_dynamics.social_environment: Vibrant, community-oriented with strong Greek life and a focus on extracurricular involvement.
campus_dynamics.transportation_impact: Primarily residential campus, walkability is high; limited public transport, parking can be an issue during events.
campus_dynamics.research_impact: Significant R&D contracts, especially in aerospace and materials science, often involving undergraduate students.

current_status.test_policy_details: The University of Dayton is test-optional, allowing applicants the choice to submit standardized test scores if they wish. Test scores are considered in the admission process if submitted. The university permits self-reporting of test scores and utilizes superscoring for the SAT, considering the highest section scores across all submitted test dates.

longitudinal_trends.notes: Acceptance rate experienced a significant decline from previous years.

gpa.notes: The average unweighted GPA for admitted students is 3.77. 33% of admitted students have perfect 4.0 GPAs in high school. 24% of admitted students were in the top 10% of their high school class.

colleges.name: College of Arts and Sciences

majors.name: Biology
majors.special_requirements: The Department of Biology maintains an updated list of laboratory courses in which dissection and/or vivisection is required.

core_courses: BIO 300 Research Experience in Biology (3 credits total over multiple enrollments)
BIO 422 Biological Problems (4 credits total over multiple enrollments)

notable_professors: Dr. Daniel Moon (Interim Provost and Senior Vice President for Academic Affairs, Instructor of Biology in Residence)
majors.notes: Offers an accelerated Bachelor and Master of Science (BPM) program in Biology, allowing completion in five years. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Communication
majors.notes: Communication majors cannot minor in their same concentration area. Offers concentrations in Communication Management, Communication Studies, Journalism, Media Production, and Public Relations. Teacher licensure available through a dual-degree B.A. and B.S.E. program. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Computer Science
majors.special_requirements: Students must attain grades of C- or better in CPS 150, CPS 151, and CPS 350.

core_courses: ASI 150 Introduction to the University Experience (1 credit)
CPS 490 Capstone I (Satisfies CAP Major Capstone)
electives: CPS 410 User Interface Design and Implementation

notable_professors: Dr. Jennifer Crissman (Professor of Information Tech & Computer Science)
majors.notes: Offers concentrations in AI and Data Science, Cyber Defense, or Software Engineering. Students may take five CPS courses numbered higher than 310 as electives. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Criminal Justice Studies
prerequisite_courses: CJS 101 Introduction to Criminal Justice Studies

core_courses: CJS 101 Introduction to Criminal Justice Studies
CJS 207 Research Methods in Criminal Justice Studies
CJS 210 Theories of Crime and Delinquency
CJS 401 Capstone Seminar in Criminal Justice Studies
electives: CJS 214 Cyber Essentials for Criminal Justice
CJS 303 Theory and Practice of Corrections

notable_professors: Dr. Jeanie J. Bukowski (Associate Professor of Political Science and Law)
majors.notes: Offers concentrations in Criminal Justice Studies, Cyber Investigations, Cyber-Security Management, and Pre-Law. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Psychology
prerequisite_courses: MTH 114, MTH 116, MTH 148, MTH 168, or MTH 207 (for PSY 216)
majors.special_requirements: Completion of PSY 101 with a C- or better and enrollment in PSY 216 is required to transfer into the major. Students who do not earn a C- or better in PSY 216 after two attempts will be required to meet with the department chairperson. Psychology majors are required to attain grades of C- or better in PSY 101, PSY 201, PSY 216, and PSY 217.

core_courses: PSY 201 History and Systems of Psychology

majors.notes: Both Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) and Bachelor of Science (B.S.) degrees are offered. The B.S. typically involves more natural science and mathematics courses. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

colleges.housing_profile: First-year students live in traditional residence halls (e.g., Marycrest, Stuart, Founders) designed to build community, typically in double or triple rooms with shared bathrooms. As sophomores, they move into suite-style apartments (e.g., Virginia W. Kettering Suite Complex, Campus South) offering increased autonomy. Upperclassmen can choose from various university-owned apartments and houses in the student neighborhood.
colleges.student_archetype: Intellectually curious and broadly engaged individuals who appreciate a liberal arts foundation. They are often involved in diverse extracurriculars, service initiatives, and may explore interdisciplinary studies.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Ideal for students who seek a comprehensive education, value critical thinking and diverse perspectives, and want to be part of a vibrant campus community that emphasizes service and personal growth.

colleges.name: School of Business Administration

majors.name: Accounting
majors.special_requirements: Minimum grade of 'C' in ACC 201 or ACC 208, and ACC 202 or ACC 207 for ACC 303 and ACC 305. Minimum grade of 'C' in ACC 303, ACC 305, ACC 306, and ACC 341. Minimum grade of 'C-' in ACC 401, ACC 408, ACC 420 and accounting electives (or 'C' if a prerequisite for an elective).
notable_professors: Dr. Michele Welkener (Associate Professor of Counselor Education and Human Services)
majors.notes: The School of Business Administration requires a minimum 3.0 GPA and successful completion of a college-level math class for transfer into any of its majors. Students pursuing a combined BSBA in Accounting and a Master of Professional Accountancy (MPAcc) may waive ACC 408 and replace it with ACC 603A. Ohio and many other states require 150 semester hours to become a CPA. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Business Analytics
majors.notes: The School of Business Administration requires a minimum 3.0 GPA and successful completion of a college-level math class for transfer into any of its majors. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

colleges.housing_profile: Similar to other schools, first-year students are housed in traditional residence halls (e.g., Marycrest, Stuart, Founders) to facilitate social integration. Sophomores typically move to suite-style accommodations or apartments. Juniors and seniors enjoy more independent living options in university-owned apartments and houses in the student neighborhood. ILLCs with a business ethics or leadership focus are available.
colleges.student_archetype: Ambitious and community-minded future leaders with a strong entrepreneurial spirit and a commitment to ethical practices. They are likely to engage in internships, real-world business projects, and leadership roles.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Prospective students interested in a top-ranked entrepreneurship program, extensive experiential learning opportunities, and a strong sense of community within a business context should consider this school. Engaging with business-focused ILLCs can provide early networking.

colleges.name: School of Education and Health Sciences

majors.name: Nursing
majors.special_requirements: Students interested in a major within the School of Education and Health Sciences must have a minimum of 3.2 GPA to be considered for admission for health science majors.
notable_professors: Dr. Cynthia J. Bowers (Associate Professor, Associate Dean, School of Nursing)
Shelby Hinspeter (Assistant Professor of Nursing in Residence)
majors.notes: The University of Dayton Nursing Program prepares students to practice as Baccalaureate generalist nurses. The program is an integrated curriculum in collaboration with Sinclair College where students complete their first three semesters at the University of Dayton. Upon completion, students earn both an Associate's of Applied Science in Nursing and a Bachelor's of Science in Nursing. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

colleges.housing_profile: Housing follows the university's progressive model: traditional dorms for freshmen (e.g., Marycrest, Stuart, Founders) focusing on community building, followed by suite-style living or apartments for sophomores. Upperclassmen often reside in the student neighborhood's university-owned houses or apartments, offering more independent living.
colleges.student_archetype: Compassionate and service-oriented individuals dedicated to improving the well-being of others. They are typically hands-on, seeking practical experience in educational or health-related fields, and value community engagement.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: This school is well-suited for students passionate about education, health, and service, who desire a supportive community and opportunities for practical, real-world experience. A commitment to community service aligns well with the university's mission.

colleges.name: School of Engineering

majors.name: Chemical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: To transfer into the School of Engineering, students must have a 3.0 cumulative GPA and B grades in Calculus 1, College/General Chemistry, and calculus-based Physics 1.
majors.notes: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Civil Engineering
majors.special_requirements: To transfer into the School of Engineering, students must have a 3.0 cumulative GPA and B grades in Calculus 1, College/General Chemistry, and calculus-based Physics 1.
notable_professors: Dr. Souhail Elhouar (Professor of Civil Engineering and Construction)
Dr. Mahmood Soltani (Associate Professor of Civil and Construction Engineering)
majors.notes: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Computer Engineering
majors.special_requirements: To transfer into the School of Engineering, students must have a 3.0 cumulative GPA and B grades in Calculus 1, College/General Chemistry, and calculus-based Physics 1.
notable_professors: Dr. Richard J. Kee (Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering)
Dr. Suruz Miah (Associate Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering)
majors.notes: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET. Draws from software courses in computer science and hardware-related courses in Electrical and Computer Engineering. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Electrical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: To transfer into the School of Engineering, students must have a 3.0 cumulative GPA and B grades in Calculus 1, College/General Chemistry, and calculus-based Physics 1.

core_courses: ECE 340 Electric Machines and Power Systems

majors.notes: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET. Offers undergraduate concentrations in Robotics and Electrical Energy Systems. The curriculum is designed to provide an understanding of basic electrical engineering principles with emphasis on the development of problem-solving skills. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

majors.name: Mechanical Engineering
majors.special_requirements: To transfer into the School of Engineering, students must have a 3.0 cumulative GPA and B grades in Calculus 1, College/General Chemistry, and calculus-based Physics 1.
majors.notes: Accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission of ABET. The curriculum includes sufficient elective courses to permit a concentration in aerospace, energy systems engineering, and other areas. Data source: University of Dayton Undergraduate Catalog 2025-2026, College Scorecard

colleges.housing_profile: First-year students reside in traditional residence halls (e.g., Marycrest, Stuart, Founders) with communal bathrooms, fostering tight-knit communities. Sophomores transition to suite-style living or apartments (e.g., Campus South, Garden Apartments), offering more privacy. Juniors and seniors have the opportunity to live in university-owned houses or apartments in the student neighborhood, providing a more independent living experience. Integrated Learning-Living Communities (ILLCs) with a focus on science and engineering are available for those seeking a themed residential experience.
colleges.student_archetype: Driven and collaborative problem-solvers who value hands-on learning and practical application. They are likely to be engaged in research, co-ops, and extracurriculars related to STEM, and appreciate a supportive community environment.
colleges.strategic_fit_advice: Students with a strong aptitude for STEM subjects, a desire for experiential learning, and an interest in a community-oriented campus should consider the School of Engineering. Active participation in ILLCs can enhance the first-year experience.

supplemental_requirements.details: The University of Dayton generally does not require supplemental essays for general admission. Some specific programs, such as honors or pre-professional programs, may have additional essay requirements.

supplemental_requirements.target_program: Music (Bachelor of Music degree programs and Music/Theatre Scholarship opportunities)
supplemental_requirements.deadline: Applications must be received at least two weeks prior to the chosen audition date. Off-schedule and virtual auditions for scholarship are available by appointment until Monday, February 16, 2026.
supplemental_requirements.details: Auditions are required for admission into undergraduate Bachelor of Music degree programs (Music Composition, Music Education, Music Performance, Music Therapy, Bachelor of Arts in Music with concentrations in Jazz Studies and Music Studies) and for all students seeking music and theatre scholarship opportunities. In-person audition dates for the 2025-2026 academic year include Saturday, January 24, 2026; Saturday, February 7, 2026; and Saturday, February 14, 2026. Off-schedule and virtual auditions for scholarship are available by appointment until Monday, February 16, 2026, by contacting the Department of Music and Theatre. Academic admission to the university is separate from the audition process.

holistic_review_factors.specific_differentiators: Whole-person approach to education within a relationship-rich community rooted in the Marianist tradition; transparent tuition plan; emphasis on high-impact experiential learning.

major_selection_tactics: Evaluate program strengths at UD, particularly in engineering and business.
Consider experiential learning opportunities like internships or co-ops unique to UD.
Align major choice with UD's Catholic, Marianist values and community focus.
college_ranking_tactics: Prioritize UD for its strong sense of community and student support services.
Value UD's commitment to hands-on learning and career preparation.
Consider UD's alumni network, particularly in the Midwest region.
application_strategy.alternate_major_strategy: If primary major at UD is highly competitive, explore related interdisciplinary programs (e.g., if engineering is full, look at industrial design or technology management) or leverage UD's flexibility for changing majors early on.

financials.notes: University of Dayton meets 88% of demonstrated need. Merit scholarships for first-year students range from $17,000 to $33,000 per year. More than 90% of undergraduates receive financial assistance.

scholarships.name: Trustees' Merit Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (e.g., Early Action: November 1, Regular Decision: February 1)
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for four years; may include textbook scholarship eligibility; considered for students with excellent GPA, test scores (if submitted), and academic rigor.

scholarships.name: President's Merit Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (e.g., Early Action: November 1, Regular Decision: February 1)
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for four years; may include textbook scholarship eligibility; awarded based on GPA, test scores (if submitted), and academic rigor.

scholarships.name: Dean's Merit Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (e.g., Early Action: November 1, Regular Decision: February 1)
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for four years; awarded based on GPA, test scores (if submitted), and rigor of coursework taken.

scholarships.name: Marianist Leadership Scholarship
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration with admission application (e.g., Early Action: November 1, Regular Decision: February 1)
scholarships.benefits: Renewable for four years; awarded based on GPA and academic excellence.

scholarships.name: International Merit Scholarship
scholarships.amount: Up to $33,000 per year (plus potential $4,000 over four years for textbooks)
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration upon receipt of application and required documents (e.g., Fall term: May 1, Spring term: November 1)
scholarships.benefits: Towards tuition costs; potential textbook scholarship; no registration fee.

scholarships.name: University Honors Program Benefits
scholarships.amount: Varies (funding for internships, research, study abroad)
scholarships.deadline: Automatic consideration upon admission or application after first semester/year
scholarships.benefits: Early registration, special advising, honors housing option, enriched educational opportunities (honors courses, research experiences), funding for internships (DC Flyers, Dublin Flyers), research (Berry Summer Thesis Institute, Oxford Flyers), faith and leadership (Chaminade Scholars).
scholarships.application_method: Automatic Consideration/Separate Application for specific programs

scholarships.name: Music and Visual Arts Scholarships
scholarships.benefits: Awards based on competitive auditions for Music, or portfolio submission for Art and Design; four-year scholarships for outstanding promise in visual arts.

ap_policy.general_rule: The University of Dayton generally awards credit for AP scores of 3, 4, or 5. Many scores of 3 award 3-4 credits for introductory courses. Scores of 4 or 5 generally award 3-6 credits, often fulfilling general education or major prerequisites, with some advanced exams offering higher credit (e.g., 6-8 credits for Calculus BC). Specific credit awards vary by subject and department.

ib_policy.general_rule: For International Baccalaureate (IB) exams, the University of Dayton typically awards credit for Higher Level (HL) exams with scores of 4, 5, 6, or 7, usually earning 3-8 credits depending on the subject. Standard Level (SL) exams generally do not award credit, though some exceptions may exist for very high scores (6 or 7) in specific subjects. Students completing the full IB Diploma may receive additional consideration.

transfer_articulation.restrictions: The University of Dayton accepts transfer credit from regionally accredited institutions, requiring a minimum grade of C- (1.70) or higher for courses to be considered. Credits are generally transferred as general education requirements, elective credit, or direct course equivalents when the content closely matches a UD course. Online courses from accredited institutions are typically accepted. There are maximum credit limits, such as 60-75 credits from a two-year institution, and generally no more than 90 total transfer credits toward a bachelor's degree. Tools and advisors are available to assist with course equivalency and articulation planning.

common_activities: Participating in student organizations (e.g., clubs, Greek life)
Engaging in service-learning projects and volunteer work
Attending athletic events and supporting Dayton Flyers teams
Utilizing campus resources like the library and academic support centers
Networking with alumni and career services for internships and jobs
essay_tips: Reflect on experiences that shaped your values and how they align with UD's mission.
Highlight your commitment to service and community involvement.
Showcase your intellectual curiosity and passion for learning.
Share specific examples of your leadership or teamwork skills.
Be authentic and let your unique voice shine through.
red_flags: Lack of demonstrated interest in community or service.
Failure to research UD's specific programs or mission.
Essays that lack personal reflection or specific examples.
Poor academic record inconsistent with UD's standards.
Inability to articulate future goals or how UD can help achieve them.
insights: University of Dayton values students who are not only academically strong but also committed to making a positive impact on their communities.
Engagement in co-curricular activities and service learning is a hallmark of the UD student experience.
Authenticity and a clear connection to UD's Marianist values are key themes for successful applicants.
Students should demonstrate how they will contribute to and benefit from UD's collaborative and service-oriented environment.
Proactive engagement with campus resources and alumni networks is common among successful UD students.

outcomes.notes: Median earnings 10 years after enrollment and 6 years after enrollment are from the College Scorecard. The employment rate is 1 year after graduation, as a 2-year specific rate from the College Scorecard was not directly available. The University of Dayton's overall graduation rate of 82% places it within the top 10% nationally.
